chunks.en: To those senior members in Guangzhou who own cars, I have a question to ask~~
Hello seniors, Happy New Year!!
I would like to ask a question about parking fees.
[Background] :
My wife won the lottery for a gasoline car license plate, so we plan to buy our first gasoline car this year.
But we haven't bought a house yet (and don't plan to in the next 2 years), so we need to find a parking space near our rented apartment.
[Question] :
Parking spaces in Guangzhou are too expensive. From what I understand, monthly parking passes generally cost around 1000~1500, which means another 1000+ in invisible expenses.
I would like to ask the seniors how they solve the problem of parking fees?
Is the ultimate solution to this problem to buy aåœè½¦ä½ parking space?
No solution. You can achieve it by spending more money.
But not many people buy parking spaces; most people rent.
1000-1500 for a monthly pass is still not that much. Maybe you live in a high-end luxury residential community.
@Takizawa On the contrary, I live in a relatively old residential area, with the highest building being only 5 floors, haha.
@Takizawa Bro, how much is your monthly parking pass? Which district are you in?

The best solution is to rent. That's the price in the city center. Buying a parking space that costs 1500 to rent would cost you 400-500k. And it's not just expensive at home, it's the same at the company, and parking at shopping malls is also expensive. Add a bit more to your budget.

Look for nearby shopping malls and office buildings that don't have cars at night. For example, I remember that the Tianhe City in Tiyu West only costs a few hundred for a monthly nighttime parking pass.
@WhoCanBeRich Tianhe District, I'm at my workplace, 300 per year ğŸ˜‚
Where do you live? My monthly parking pass in Shiqiao, Panyu is 400.
1. Parking space fee 6000+/year
2. Insurance 4000+/year
3. Maintenance 1000+/year
4. Gasoline car 9L/100km, 64 yuan/100km
Those around me who bought gasoline cars have all regretted it, including me. I'm already planning to switch to a pure electric car, after 2+ years.
A monthly parking pass of 1000+ is basically in the downtown area.
A car is not a necessity. I suggest giving up the license plate.
If you win the lottery for a license plate in Guangzhou, you can postpone it. I think it's a year and a half or a year in total? No rush.
How often do you use the car?
If you rarely use the car, or basically don't use it at all, and you live in the old four districts, give up the license plate. It's a burden if you buy one.

chunks.en: If you have children, a family car is a must in 2-3 years. If you don't want to spend a lot of money right now, you can consider buying a car that costs 7-8k, is 10+ years old, but can still run. Maintain the license plate by getting the annual inspection done by a scalper. Start the car every two weeks. When you change to a new car, you can scrap it or sell it for 2-3k.
Park the car in a suburban parking lot.
If you think the above is also a waste of money, give up the license plate and bid for one when you need a car.

Let me be blunt here. Although the four-days-driving-four-days-stopping policy is gone, they've implemented rush hour restrictions. Sooner or later, Guangzhou will implement deeper restrictions and license plate restrictions within the city ring. It's too congested.
Except for 7-seaters (which are expensive with batteries), I suggest buying an electric car, either hybrid or pure electric.
You need to specify where you are referring for the monthly pass fee.

There is no solution to parking fees, and I also don't recommend trying to save on parking fees by fiddling with parking. Including buying and maintaining the car, it will cost you at least three to four thousand a month on average. Evaluate whether buying a car can bring a corresponding improvement in the quality of life before deciding. A car is purely a consumer product.
Buy a car and rent it out, so you don't need a parking space.
@Takizawa #6 Are workplaces so extravagant now? Do you have to pay for parking to work there?
Parking fees are a must.
Otherwise, it's a hassle to look for a car everywhere when you need to use it.
But a normal monthly pass isn't usually this expensive.
Look for nearby parking lots?
But that's troublesome, especially in rainy or hot weather. You'll get soaked or sweaty running to the car. So spend a little extra money to improve your happiness.
@pppguest3962 #12 This hasn't been implemented yet, right?
I feel like it can't be implemented. After all, there are too many surrounding cities. As the capital of the province, Guangzhou still needs to consider the travel needs of surrounding cities.

@canyue7897 #18 Yes, yes, it's too congested. Tianhe and Zhujiang New Town, the overpass, the Inner Ring Road West, feel like the rush hour restrictions aren't working. The only way to improve it might be to increase the restriction dosage.

Speaking of which, this rush hour restriction has blocked residents of Zhongshan, Foshan, Qingyuan, and Jiangmen from driving to major hospitals in the provincial capital for treatment on the same day, forcing people to arrive in Guangzhou the night before to stay in a hotel.
@canyue7897 It's different... we are a work unit not a company, we usually live inside as well.
